awd_titl_txt: Toward Precision Cosmology on Small Scales: A Data-Intensive Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a wealth of information about both cosmology and galaxy formation encoded in small scales, but the relevant physics is poorly understood and computationally prohibitive.  Halo-based models bypass this problem by parameterizing the relation between galaxies and dark-matter halos, but contain systematic errors and are not sufficiently accurate for reliable statistical tests.  A new data-intensive approach that this team has made computationally tractable constructs realistic catalogs from simulations and measures clustering statistics exactly as is done for real data.  This work will move past proof-of-concept to perform stringent tests of the Lambda-Cold-Dark-Matter (LCDM) cosmological model on small scales.  The result will be a software emulator that uses a grid of simulations to predict galaxy clustering statistics as a function of both cosmology and galaxy-halo parameters.  All mock catalogs and analysis codes will be publicly released, which will enable many additional projects.  The project also adds training in the critical area of statistics and data analysis to the current Fisk-Vanderbilt bridge program that helps students from underrepresented groups move into a PhD program.

The current system has already been used to test fixed cosmological models against measurements in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, revealing significant tension with the simplest form of the LCDM plus halo model.  This next study will be carried out by identifying optimal measurements, extending the parameterization of the galaxy-halo relation to allow for subtle features (including non-Poisson statistics, spatial and velocity bias, and galaxy assembly bias), and strengthening the modeling pipeline.  This will enable the most stringent tests of fixed cosmological models, and probe those subtle features of the galaxy-halo connection that have been added.  The final ambitious part of the project is to allow cosmological parameters to vary within the parameter search, by exploiting approximate methods to use a single cosmology simulation to predict the halo distributions of other cosmologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Large galaxy surveys that have mapped the spatial distribution of galaxies in 3D space, such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), showed that galaxies are highly clustered in space. Some regions of the universe are highly dense, containing thousands of galaxies in close spatial proximity, while others are largely empty. The detailed clustering patterns of galaxies on both small and large scales encode a wealth of information about the initial conditions of the universe and the big questions that cosmologists are after: what is the universe made of? what is its history? what is dark matter and dark energy? Measurements of galaxy clustering on large scales have provided strong constraints on these cosmological quantities. Clustering on small scales contains even more information but it is extremely challenging to extract because on these scales the spatial distribution of galaxies also depends on the detailed physics of galaxy formation, which are poorly understood. One powerful way to attack this problem is to exploit the fact that all galaxies reside in dense regions of dark matter, called ‘halos’, whose properties depend mainly on cosmology and gravity, and are thus easy to predict. By parameterizing the relationship between the numbers and locations of galaxies that reside in these halos and the properties of the halos, it is possible to predict the small-scale clustering of galaxies, bypassing the unknowns of galaxy formation. Those unknowns are represented in a simple way by the parameters of the galaxy-halo relationship and they can be empirically determined by comparing the predictions of this ‘halo model’ to observations of galaxy clustering in the universe. 

To take advantage of the enormous amount of information in surveys like the SDSS, it is critically important to extract as much of the information as possible and to have a halo model that is as accurate as possible and has well-understood uncertainties. Prior to this work, studies had only used one or two simple clustering statistics to quantify galaxy clustering and they had adopted halo models that were too restrictive and did not encapsulate all the possible ways that galaxies can reside within halos. As a result, no study was able to convincingly place constraints on cosmology using these methods. The goals of this work were to address both these limitations and perform the first reliable test of cosmology on small scales using SDSS data. In the first phase of this project, we developed a halo-based model that was built on large simulations of the universe and was capable of predicting any arbitrary galaxy clustering statistic with a high degree of accuracy. Furthermore, we investigated an extensive set of clustering statistics and determined the optimal combination of measurements for constraining our halo model using SDSS data. Our work demonstrated that it is possible to obtain much stronger constraints on model parameters than before. In the second phase of this project, we developed a flexible halo model that more fully encapsulated the galaxy-halo relationship. We also studied the extent to which the unknowns of galaxy formation physics might impact our ability to correctly predict the properties of halos – something which has been ignored in all previous works. Armed with our optimal set of clustering statistics and our flexible model, we tested our model against SDSS data and obtained the tightest constraints on the galaxy-halo relationship to-date. We found that low luminosity galaxies exhibit the phenomena known as ‘assembly bias’ and ‘satellite velocity bias’, while luminous galaxies do not. More importantly, we found significant tension between our model and SDSS data. We showed that this is unlikely due to the unknowns of galaxy formation and is thus evidence that our adopted cosmology (the “Planck LCDM” model) may be incorrect.

As part of this project, two graduate students were trained and completed their PhD dissertations. Additionally, several classes of students in the Fisk-Vanderbilt Masters-to-PhD program received training in statistical data analysis methods as part of an annual statistics boot-camp.
